awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Deformation Induced Soil Fracturing - Multi-Scale Multi-Physics Mechanism and Early Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project investigates the fundamental science of multi-scale and multi-physics processes of fractures that develop in soil while a soil mass is settling and deforming due to land subsidence, landslides or earthquakes.  It seeks experimental evidence of a new theoretical model of soil fracturing.  The findings will then be used to develop a field monitoring tool that provides early warning of soil fracturing.  The project specifically utilizes the following two problems in geotechnical engineering as part of a case scenario-based study.  The first problem is related to land subsidence induced by groundwater extraction that is prevalent in many areas of the United States.  For example, in the San Joaquin Valley, California, more than half of the valley has subsided in excess of 0.3m; subsidence of 10 m and a rate of more than 0.3m/year has been reported in some areas.  When differential compaction occurs near groundwater extraction wells and local variations in geology, cracks may develop in the surrounding ground.  Such land subsidence induced fracture zones may be as much as 200 m wide and consist of multiple parallel, branching fissures and graben blocks.  These features are reported to cause billions of dollars of damage to critical built infrastructure. However, monitoring technology that effectively gives early warning to soil fracture development is not available at present.  The second problem is related to possible earthquake-induced damage of deep cut-off walls used in river levees that are constructed to reduce its flood risk.  For example, the Greater Sacramento area in California is among the most at-risk regions in America for catastrophic flooding.  The area relies on an aging system of levees, and massive levee improvements are currently underway.  A typical improvement involves installation of deep cut off walls with additional fill to raise the levee in order to mitigate under-seepage failure of the levees.  During an earthquake, the walls can be at risk of fracturing as the levee system deforms.  As a consequence, the ability to control seepage in a future flooding event may be lost. Again, an early warning monitoring system is needed to assess the risk of such soil fractures during the lifetime of operation.

When soil fracture occurs, it is likely to be localized and scale-dependent and therefore the locations of the failure will be difficult to predict. This uncertainty in the soil fracturing process can potentially lead to significant engineering issues and any monitoring technology that provides early detection is needed. To make a step change in our fundamental understanding of soil fracturing process, experimental evidence that supports new theoretical models and tools to measure it in the field are required.  This project aims to explore for the experimental evidence of multi-physics and multi-scale soil-pore water interaction occurring during deformation induced soil fracture initiation and propagation and to demonstrate the feasibility of high resolution distributed fiber optic strain sensing technology for detecting an early signature of soil fracturing.  The primary goals of the project are (i) test for experimental evidence of multi-physics and multi-scale soil-pore water interaction occurring during deformation induced soil fracture initiation and propagation, and (ii) to demonstrate the feasibility of high resolution distributed fiber optic strain sensing technology for detecting an early signature of soil fracturing.  In this project, a series of flexural tests will be performed on soil beam specimens, in which miniature pore pressure transducers and fiber optic sensing cables will be embedded.  The project will investigate the excess pore pressure generation and dissipation during the soil fracture initiation and propagation process.  It is hypothesized that different micro-scale failure modes inside a fracture process zone would be captured by high resolution distributed fiber optic strain sensing technology. The feasibility of the technology for a field-based early warning system against soil fracturing will be examined.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the fundamental science of multi-scale and multi-physics processes of fractures that develop in the soil while a soil body mass is settling and deforming due to ground deformation such as land subsidence, landslides, or earthquakes. The treatment of soil fracturing in geotechnical engineering has been historically empirical, and the academic knowledge is limited compared to that of the shear and compression behavior of soil. There are no formal soil fracture criteria in academic textbooks and engineering practice. This is partly because (a) non-cemented particle assembly is considered to have zero tensile capacity (in effective stress) and hence the effect is often ignored, (b) tensile experiments are challenging to perform because of low confinement, and (c) there are limited good geotechnical engineering case studies that analyze soil fracture failures in detail. However, many geomaterials (cemented soil (natural or manmade), heavily overconsolidated clay) carry tensile capacity but are also brittle. When soil fracture occurs, it is likely to be localized and scale-dependent and hence the locations of the failure will be difficult to predict. This uncertainty in the soil fracturing process can potentially lead to significant engineering issues. Once soil fracturing occurs, it may be too late for any remedial work to be performed, and therefore any monitoring technology that provides early detection will be helpful.

The research examined a hypothesized soil-pore fluid interaction mechanism of deformation-induced soil fracture. The study attempted to measure the change in pore pressure as the soil starts to fracture. A newly miniature pore pressure sensor of 1 mm diameter was developed by housing an innovative fiber optic-based pressure transducer used in the medical measurement in a small porous ceramic tip. The sensor was used to measure the pore pressure response at the crack tip before fracture development in a soil specimen under the tensile loading conditions. Results show that when soil fracture started to initiate, there was a decrease in pore pressure. The data were used to demonstrate that soil fracturing is not only scale-dependent but also time or rate-dependent. 

This study also utilized an innovative distributed fiber optic strain sensor (DSS) system as the primary technology to measure the initiation and development of soil fracture. It was proposed as a potentially promising tool for early detection of soil fracture initiation in the field. The main advantage of this technology is that spatially continuous strain data (say every few centimeters) for 5-10 km length standard optical fiber cable can be obtained. Capturing the continuous strain profile will be helpful to pinpoint localized problem areas such as soil fractures. It was hypothesized that high-resolution distributed fiber optic strain sensing technology could potentially detect an early signature of soil fracturing with a fracture opening of 10 microns.

A series of bending experiments were conducted on beam specimens made of cemented geomaterials (sand-cement mortar mixture and slug cement-cement-bentonite (SCCB) mixture) and compacted kaolin clay to investigate the detailed distributed strain profile around deformation induced fracture. Based on the distributed strain profiles at different locations of the loaded beam, the data from the DSS system were used to understand the strain behavior and deformation mechanisms under various loading conditions. The feasibility of the system in capturing different fracture features was examined. The beam experiments were numerically simulated using the 3D Lattice Element Method (LEM), which is a discontinuous numerical model using a truss or frame structure to simulate mechanical response and fracture behavior of solid effectively. As the model simulated the process of crack development, the computed strain distribution across the specimen during the whole process was used to investigate the influence of crack development on adjacent strain fields. A new data interpretation method of the distributed fiber optic sensing data was also developed to give an early warning of soil fracture generation when a fiber optic sensing cable is installed for several kilometers in a geotechnical structure.

Based on the finding from the laboratory investigation that DSS can detect the locations and magnitude of soil fracture, its feasibility for field monitoring was examined by installing fiber optic cables in a slug cement-cement-bentonite (SCCB) seepage cut-off wall during the retrofit construction of a river levee in Sacramento, CA. Temperature and strain measurements of the fiber optic cable installed SCCB wall have been conducted for more than one year since construction. The fieldwork showed that the distributed strain and temperature change data from the construction stage to the in-service stage provided an improved understanding of the long-term performance of the instrumented seepage cut-off wall.

The scientific evidence obtained and the sensing tools developed in this study can be used to make a step-change in our fundamental understanding of soil fracturing. This, in turn, will allow the geotechnical engineering community to develop a new methodology that solves problems associated with deformation-induced soil fracturing.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Kenichi Soga
